questions.text: An 8-year-old boy with a recent history of sore throat and fever now presents with jerky, uncontrollable, and purposeless movements involving his hands, arms, shoulders, face, legs, and trunk. These choreiform movements worsen with stress and disappear during sleep. His parents also report a noticeable decline in his handwriting and academic performance. On auscultation, a mid-diastolic murmur is heard at the apex. Which of the following basal ganglia structures is primarily affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The child's presentation is consistent with Sydenham's chorea, a post-streptococcal autoimmune complication of rheumatic fever. It affects the neostriatum, which includes the caudate nucleus and putamen.

  • Sydenham's chorea causes selective destruction of D2 dopamine-sensitive neurons in the neostriatum.
  • The involuntary, purposeless movements and emotional lability are hallmark signs.
  • It is one of the major criteria in the Jones criteria for rheumatic fever diagnosis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Caudate nucleus and globus pallidus (Option A): This combination is not classically affected in Sydenham's chorea. The globus pallidus is more associated with Parkinsonian features.

Globus pallidus and putamen (Option B): These form the lentiform nucleus, but Sydenham's chorea primarily targets the neostriatum (caudate + putamen).

Globus pallidus and lentiform nucleus (Option D): This is a repetitive option, as globus pallidus is already part of the lentiform nucleus. It is not the primary site in chorea.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a component of the limbic system?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The limbic system is a functional network of cortical and subcortical structures involved in memory, emotion, and behaviour. The lateral thalamic nuclei are part of the sensory relay system and are not directly involved in the limbic circuitry.

Core components of the limbic system include:

  • Cingulate gyrus
  • Hippocampus
  • Parahippocampal gyrus
  • Mammillary bodies
  • Anterior thalamic nuclei
  • Septal nuclei
  • Amygdaloid body

Papez Circuit (limbic loop) includes:

  • Hippocampus → Fornix → Mammillary bodies → Mammillothalamic tract → Anterior thalamic nuclei → Cingulate gyrus → Cingulum → Parahippocampal gyrus → Entorhinal cortex → Hippocampus

This circuit is essential for memory consolidation and emotional processing.

Explanation of Other Options:

Mammillary body (Option A): Part of the hypothalamus; relays information from the hippocampus to the anterior thalamus via the mammillothalamic tract.

Septal nuclei (Option B): Involved in reward and reinforcement; connected to the hippocampus and hypothalamus.

Cingulate gyrus (Option D): Involved in emotion formation and processing; receives input from anterior thalamic nuclei and projects to the hippocampus.

choices.text: Putamen and globus pallidus are separated by the internal medullary lamina.
Putamen and globus pallidus are separated by the external medullary lamina.
The internal capsule separates the lentiform complex from the caudate nucleus.
The external capsule separates the claustrum from the putamen.

questions.text: Which statement is wrong regarding the highlighted structure shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The putamen and globus pallidus are separated by the external medullary lamina.

  • The internal medullary lamina lies between the globus pallidus interna and externa.
  • The external medullary lamina separates the putamen from the globus pallidus externus.
  • The internal capsule lies between the caudate nucleus and lentiform nucleus (putamen + globus pallidus).
  • The external capsule lies between the putamen and the claustrum.

From deep to superficial, the order of structures of the basal ganglia in the horizontal section is as follows:

  • Caudate nucleus (innermost)
  • Internal capsule
  • Globus pallidus internal (GPi)
  • Internal medullary lamina
  • Globus pallidus external (GPe)
  • External medullary lamina
  • Putamen
  • External capsule
  • Claustrum
  • Extreme capsule
  • Insular cortex (outermost)

Structured Arrangement of Basal Ganglia Components (Lateral to Medial):

BASAL GANGLIA is formed by the corpus striatum

The corpus striatum is made up of 2 structures

  1. Caudate nucleus
  2. Lentiform nucleus
  • Lentiform nucleus = putamen +globus pallidus
  • The putamen and globus pallidum are separated from each other by the external medullary lamina.
  • Globus pallidus = internus +externus (separated by internal medullary lamina )

choices.text: The lesion is in the subthalamic nucleus
The movements are violent and of large amplitude
The movements are seen ipsilateral to the side of the lesion

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the lesion in the marked structure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lesions in the subthalamic nucleus lead to hemiballismus, a type of hyperkinetic movement disorder.

  • Hemiballismus is characterised by violent, large-amplitude, involuntary flinging movements of the proximal limbs.
  • These movements occur contralateral to the lesion because the subthalamic nucleus influences movement via its projections to the internal segment of the globus pallidus and substantia nigra pars reticulata, which modulate thalamocortical output.
  • The movements are seen contralateral to the side of the lesion, i.e., involuntary movements of the right arm and leg are seen in the lesion of the left subthalamic nucleus and vice versa.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • The lesion is in the subthalamic nucleus (Option A): Hemiballismus classically follows damage to the subthalamic nucleus.
  • The movements are violent and of large amplitude (Option B): Movements are typically flinging and involve proximal musculature.
  • This condition is called hemiballismus (Option C): True. Hemiballismus is the correct name for this hyperkinetic syndrome.

questions.text: A patient presents with difficulty swallowing, hoarseness, dizziness, nausea and vomiting, rapid involuntary eye movements (nystagmus), ataxia, and loss of pain and temperature sensation on one side of the face. MRI confirms Wallenberg syndrome. Based on the angiographic image provided, which of the following arteries is responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Wallenberg syndrome, or lateral medullary syndrome, is typically caused by occlusion of the vertebral artery or its branch, the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA). In this case, the left vertebral artery (marked A) is implicated.

  • The brain has a vast network of arteries that deliver blood and oxygen to all parts of the brain. Without this oxygen, brain tissue quickly begins to die. This often results in a stroke.
  • About 80% of cases of Wallenberg syndrome are caused by blockage of the vertebral artery, which supplies blood to the brainstem. Blood clots, fatty plaque deposits, or other particles can all cause blockage, resulting in an ischemic stroke that can lead to brain damage and Wallenberg syndrome.
  • Wallenberg syndrome may also be caused by a tear in or damage to the vertebral artery.
  • Vertebral artery tears are the most common cause of Wallenberg syndrome in patients younger than 45 years old.
  • Key symptoms include:
    • Dysphagia and hoarseness are due to the involvement of the nucleus ambiguus.
    • Vertigo, nausea, vomiting, and nystagmus from vestibular nuclei infarction.
    • Ipsilateral facial loss of pain and temperature (spinal trigeminal nucleus).
    • Contralateral body loss of pain and temperature (spinothalamic tract).
    • Ipsilateral ataxia due to inferior cerebellar peduncle involvement.

Explanation of Other Options:

D (Option A): Right Anterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (RDAICA); Occlusion of RDAICA leads to lateral inferior pontine syndrome, not lateral medullary syndrome. It typically affects the facial nucleus, cochlear nuclei, and middle cerebellar peduncle, causing ipsilateral facial paralysis, hearing loss, and ataxia, distinct from the findings in Wallenberg syndrome.

C (Option B): Right Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA); While PICA is a common cause of Wallenberg syndrome, the angiogram in this question specifically marks the left vertebral artery (A). PICA arises from the vertebral artery and may be implicated, but the correct vessel in this case is the left vertebral artery, as shown.

B (Option C): Basilar Artery; Occlusion of the basilar artery causes "locked-in syndrome", characterised by quadriplegia, mutism, and preserved consciousness, due to bilateral infarction of the ventral pons; this does not match the clinical profile of Wallenberg syndrome.

questions.text: A patient presents with right-sided facial paralysis along with loss of pain and temperature over the right face and left leg. Where is the most likely location of the lesion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above clinical scenario is suggestive of lateral pontine syndrome, which occurs due to a lesion located at the lateral pons.

  • Lateral pontine syndrome occurs due to the involvement of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery.
  • Ipsilateral manifestations include:
    • CN VII: Facial paralysis
    • CN V: loss of pain and temperature sensation over the face.
    • Vestibular nerve or nucleus: Horizontal and vertical nystagmus, vertigo, nausea, vomiting, oscillopsia.
    • Auditory nerve or cochlear nucleus: Deafness, tinnitus.
    • Middle cerebellar peduncle: Ataxia of limb and gait.
    • Contralateral manifestations include:
    • Spinothalamic tract: Loss of pain and temperature sensation over the body.

Nuclei and Tracts Involved in Lateral Pontine Syndrome:

Explanation of Other Options:

Medial medulla (Option A): Causes medial medullary syndrome - contralateral hemiparesis (pyramids), contralateral proprioception loss (medial lemniscus), and ipsilateral tongue paralysis (CN XII).

Medial pons (Option C): Would affect corticospinal tract and medial lemniscus, leading to contralateral weakness and vibration/proprioception loss, not facial paralysis and pain/temp loss.

Lateral medulla (Option D): Affects spinal tract of CN V and spinothalamic tract (similar to pons) but includes CN IX/X involvement (dysphagia, hoarseness) and spares CN VII.

choices.text: The tectum lies posterior to the cerebral aqueduct
The superior colliculi are centres for visual reflexes
The trochlear nerve emerges in the midline below the superior colliculi
The inferior colliculi are auditory centres, and the inferior brachium connects the inferior colliculus to the medial geniculate body

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with right-sided hemiplegia and left-sided ptosis, lateral deviation of the eyeball, and a fixed pupil unreactive to light. MRI shows infarction in the midbrain involving the oculomotor nerve and crus cerebri. Which of the following is NOT true regarding this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a classical case of Weber Syndrome, which occurs due to infarction involving the oculomotor nerve (CN III) and crus cerebri in the midbrain, often caused by occlusion of a branch of the posterior cerebral artery.

  • The oculomotor nerve lesion causes ptosis, lateral deviation of the eye (due to unopposed lateral rectus and superior oblique), and pupillary dilation.
  • The corticospinal tract involvement in the crus cerebri leads to contralateral hemiplegia.

The midbrain connects the pons and cerebellum with the forebrain. Externally, on the posterior surface, there are two pairs of colliculi-the corpora quadrigemina:

  • The superior colliculi are centres for visual reflexes. The superior brachium connects the superior colliculi to the lateral geniculate body and the optic tract.
  • The inferior colliculi are auditory centres, and the inferior brachium connects the inferior colliculus to the medial geniculate body.

The trochlear nerve emerges in the midline below the inferior colliculi.

Explanation of Other Options:

The tectum lies posterior to the cerebral aqueduct (Option A): This is anatomically correct as per midbrain cross-sections.

The superior colliculi are centres for visual reflexes (Option B): Correct; involved in the coordination of head and eye movement in response to visual stimuli.

The inferior colliculi are auditory centres, and the inferior brachium connects the inferior colliculus to the medial geniculate body (Option D): Correct; they relay auditory information to the medial geniculate body.

questions.text: An electrician experienced a 10,000 V shock through his body and suffered third-degree burns on his hands and scalp. Diffusion tensor imaging showed damage to the right medial lemniscus tract. This is formed by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a medial lemniscus tract lesion following a high-voltage electrical injury. The medial lemniscus is formed by the internal arcuate fibres. It is also called Reil's ribbon.

  • The internal arcuate fibres are axons of the second-order neurons from the nucleus gracilis and the nucleus cuneatus. In the upper medulla, they decussate and form the medial lemniscus, which synapses in the thalamus.
  • These fibres cross the midline (sensory decussation) anterior to the central canal.
  • After crossing, they ascend as the medial lemniscus and relay to the ventral posterolateral nucleus (VPL) of the thalamus.
  • This pathway is responsible for transmitting fine touch, vibration, and conscious proprioception from the opposite side of the body.

Explanation of Other Options:

Anterior external arcuate fibres (Option A): Arise from the arcuate nuclei and run anterior to the pyramid; not involved in forming the medial lemniscus.

Posterior external arcuate fibres (Option C): Originate from the accessory cuneate nucleus and relate to unconscious proprioception via the cuneocerebellar tract.

External arcuate fibres (Option D): A non-specific term; more accurately described as anterior or posterior external arcuate fibres with different functions.

questions.text: What is the structure marked '?' in the image below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked structure is the pineal gland, a small cone-shaped structure attached to the posterior wall of the third ventricle by the pineal stalk, lying posterior to the midbrain.

  • It is an important neuroendocrine organ that secretes melatonin, helping regulate circadian rhythms.
  • Histologically, it contains pinealocytes and brain sand (concretions), as seen in the stained image with hematoxylin and eosin.

(Other options are ruled out)

A= Midbrain

B= Pons

choices.text: A - CN IV, B - CN III, C - CN IX, D - CN XII
A - CN III, B - CN V, C - CN VIII, D - CN XI
A - CN VI, B - CN V, C - CN VII, D - CN IX
A - CN II, B - CN IV, C - CN X, D - CN XII

questions.text: Which cranial nerve is marked in the image shown below?
Which structure is present on the floor of the fourth ventricle in the medullary cross-section at the level of the olives?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The floor of the fourth ventricle at the level of the medulla oblongata (specifically at the level of the olive) contains the dorsal nucleus of the vagus medially.

Explanation of Other Options:

Trapezoid body (Option B): A transverse bundle found in the caudal pons, involved in the auditory pathway, not seen at the olive level.

Superior vestibular nucleus (Option C): Located in the upper pons, part of the vestibular complex lateral to the fourth ventricle.

Nucleus gracilis (Option D): Found in the dorsal medulla, but posterior to the floor of the fourth ventricle.
